bug.short_desc: extensible models framework

long_desc.thetext: As discussed at JEE 5 Working Group meeting Dec 07, 2006 an infrastructure that allows for extensibility of wtp models is required. Such an infrastructure will support a seamless integration of vendor specific models into WTP. Documents describing the concept being researched at SAP will be attached shortly. Perhaps in 1 - 1.5 weeks.

Created an attachment (id=56328) model extensibility concept
Hi, I'm attaching promissed documents. The wp.zip file contains the document in html format. Sorry for being that late. The document shows our early consideration and intention. At the end there is a small consideration section that adds few words for possible alternatives
Regards, Hristo

Thanks for providing this document and kicking off the discussions. As for comments
Pluses: - It provides capability to have different models and modeling technologies co-exist. WTP currently provides EMF based models only.
- It provides a capability to extend these models
My concerns are mostly for scheduling this work. We should:
- Review available DOM-like modeling technologies which can offer similar capabilities before we start building our own.
- The proposal is extensive, WTP v2.0 time frame is too short to do it properly. We should make this one of the top agenda items for v3.0.
However, we can review what can be done for v2.0, so that existing JEE5 models may be wrapped as a "model element". At least we should not prevent an adopter to go ahead and implement this concept.

I also want to thank Hristo for providing this concept paper. This is veryu usefull in discussing requirments for the models moving forward, and discussing our options.
To help frame this discussion I split my responses into two categories
1) Requirements for the JEE5 models in WTP 2) Introducing a model abstraction layer
After reading through your proposal I have gathered the following requirements a) Provide an pluggable model registration that allows adopters to write thier own model that implements a common set of interfaces and services. b) Allow the registered models to use different persistance mechanisms (XML, annotation, other..) c) Allow these models to be "extended" for vendor specific behavior, with a generic api for traversing these extended models, and kepping them in synch with the base model.
I agree with some of the above requirements, and to a degree the existing EMF infrastructure already satisfies a few of these requirements. We would need to create a "registration" extension point similar to your modelbuilder, although I'm not a fan of the overused term "builder" - maybe "manager". This registration should initially be against a known set of interface classes that are also registered.. Perhaps - EJB3, or Servlet25. These interfaces could be generic with no EMF specific api or dependencies. These registered implementations could have different serialized artifacts (XML, Java, etc), and listening mechanism's would be specific to the model implementations (EMF item providers for EMF models, custom listening mechanism for custom model technology etc.) Today - The "EditModel" mechanism in use today as an EMF specific aggregation of multiple resources that comprise a single domain model. Extending these models are handled by registering a new resource with the domain ("ejb, servlet, etc). The resources are managed as a single unit. To abstract this mechanism to a non EMF technology is out of scope for this project, and too much to bite off this release.
The idea of introducing a new modelling abstraction layer for generic traversal of arbitrary models doesn't seem appropriate for this project, and really should be proposed to the Eclipse Modelling Project. I understand the desire to remove EMF dependencies, and this needs to be considered for JEE5, but I would prefer creating domain specific interfaces that can be implemented using any modeling technology.

Hi Chuck,
Thanks for the comments. As discussed on the Jee5 conf call they are very reasonable.
Can you share some details about how "EditModel" can be use to extend an EMF model? I was trying to find some info about EditModel on the net. However unless you meant "EMFEdit" there's really nothing one could read to get an idea.
Regards, Hristo
I'm closing this for now..... Please reopen if the IModelProvider framework isn't satisfying these requirements.

bug.short_desc: Queries should be able to override "completed tasks" filter.

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: Project managers may wish to have separate queries for issues that are resolved and needs to be verified and closed. These will not be displayed in normal circumstances.
More information: When the "completed tasks" filter is applied (which probably is the case most of the time), no issues will show in these queries. It would be useful if one could override this filter in a query and display the issue summary using the normal presentation. A checkbox image overlay on the query folder could illustrate the special nature of the query.
This could be added as an option to the existing query pages.
Yes, that was my idea too. It should be fairly straightforward. I can lend a hand and provide a patch unless any of project members feel they want it.

Torkild: before submitting a patch, could you please post a brief description of the exact UI change that you would like to see, and how this will be used? We have to make sure that this kind of filter suppression does not result in confusion because filters will then have a custom mode, more of these modes might be requested, etc. Fyi, the way I current work-around this is to "Go Into" a query and turn the filter off then, and when I'm done with it, to go up to the root.
Mik, I guess you mean "...turn Focus on Workweek off"?

Yes, you would need to have both Focus on Workweek and the Filter Completed Tasks off to see all completed tasks.
I was actually wondering if the better way to do this would be along the lines of making the Focus on Workweek more configurable. For example, instead of showing just the tasks completed today it could show tasks completed this week. But as usual we have to tread carefully here in order not to bloat the UI.
Once we have day 'bins' in the Focus on Workweek mode then exposing completed tasks in the day they were completed would make a lot of sense to me.
Sounds right. Let's revisit this once we have done bug 147084 and put some mileage on that UI.

Bug 147084 is completed and released with 2.0M2.
Torkild: do you still need the support described here?

(In reply to comment #8) > Bug 147084 is completed and released with 2.0M2. > > Torkild: do you still need the support described here? > Yes, we do need to display resolved but unclosed issues in a good manner. I was planning to do something about this myself but got too busy with the just released Eclipse based AVR32 Studio (http://www.atmel.com/dyn/products/tools_card.asp?tool_id=4116). I'm still at 3.2 so I have not tested the new merged view. I'll do that ASAP and let you know if this issue can be closed without further due.
Ah, of course the new version also supports Eclipse 3.2. I took it for a spin and found that the requested enhancement is not covered. I'll see what I can do about it.

ClasspathManager calls adapor hooks with wrong bytecode

long_desc.thetext: While implementing the caching service for the aspect weaving I run into a problem getting the modified class bytes from the hook. Seems like "findClassImpl" in "ClasspathManager" calls the hook method "recordClassDefine" with the original loaded class bytes and not the modified ones (they might be modified within the "defineClass" method of the same class).
Created an attachment (id=55576) Patch for the ClasspathManager
Is there a workaround for 3.2 or is there any chance that this gets fixed for 3.2?
I will investigate for 3.2.2.

Martin, is a possible workaround for you to store your changed classbyte array in a thread local variable in your ClassLoadingHook and then get that classbyte array from the thread local variable in your ClassLoadingStatsHook? This will not work if other ClassLoadingHooks change the bytes after your hook. Not nice, I think we should fix this for 3.2.2. I will attach a patch to 3.3 and 3.2.x streams. Your patch is against the aspect incubator org.eclipse.osgi project.

Created an attachment (id=55593) 3.2.x patch
Patch against 3.2.x stream. Jeff do you approve this fix for 3.2.2? It is a simple fix.

Patch released to 3.2.2.

Yes, please. However, I quickly tried it with methods, and my scenarios with and without parameters always worked fine (with scary warnings, but that's intended;-).

bug.short_desc: Exception message should be more specific when there is no permission to launch the application

long_desc.thetext:
When trying to launch an application with no permission to execute, we get the following messages:
On Linux: "Error: The process launch command execution failed. There is no such application. The error code and error info - 6003 and "Unable to Start Process : File is Not Executable"
It's a quite clear message.
On Windows: "Error: The process launch command execution failed. There is no such application. The error code and error info - 6003 and "Unable to Start Process : Unspecified Process Controller Error"
I'd be much better to get something like "Access denied" instead of "Unspecified Process Controller Error".
Retargetting to future
Transferring ownership of new agemt controller issues with no specific target date to Mikhail for consideration in future releases.

For information on temporary workarounds contact: jvmpi_eol@sun.com Could not resolve to JVMPI interface Error occurred during initialization of VM -Xrun library failed to init: piAgent
I really think this is an Eclipse bug 'coz i had sent a bug request to sun and they told me that
"JVMPI is the old, and experimental, profiling interface. It was never part of the platform specification and was deprecated in J2SE 5.0. Its replacement is the JSR-163 specified JVM Tool Interface (JVM TI) that was added in J2SE 5.0. Since 5.0 the documentation on the java.sun.com site was updated to alert developers that this interface would be removed in a future release. A further step towards its removal took place in Java SE 6 when the interface was "disabled", and the plan is to remove the code completely in Java SE 7 "
so these are the things abt this bug...
I guess that when you said Eclipse profiler you mean TPTP one (Eclipse SDK has no profiler...) => Move to TPTP project

bug.short_desc: Annotation support for retry at the proxy level

long_desc.thetext:
It has been suggested that we need an easy way to enable the SOA framework to deal with network issues. For certain types of operations (namely idempotent operations), the framework can safely retry the operation when a recoverable network exception is encountered.
The easiest way to provide this sort of support is via annotation, where methods of the interface presented to the proxy factory, or the interface itself, are annotated to indicate that the operations may be retried without side-effects.
For cases where more care is needed, we currently propogate a SOANetworkException - which by inspection is thrown when a recoverable network error is encountered (As we have a SOAUnrecoverableNetworkException, perhapswe need a name change to indicate that the exception may be retried?). For non-annotated methods, this exception is allowed to go back to the invoker, who may decide to retry or not.
A new strategy mechanism implemented and checked in to support more flexible annotation mechanism.
Some decisions should be made for the default reconnection mechanism. Currently the default is the count strategy with 5 tries to server.
Marked as close for 1.0.0M8 build

bug.short_desc: New AC does not start on Vista

long_desc.thetext:
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Install AC 2. Add <ac>\bin to system path 3. Configure AC (by running SetConfig.bat) 4. Run ACServer.exe
The AC fails to start saying:
Error starting transport layers, Agent controller exiting. See servicelog.log for error report.

Created an attachment (id=55584) AC service log file
Attached AC log file

Assigning to Igor and targetting 4.2.2.
Igor turned on logging in TransportSupportSharedMem.c giving the following output:
C:\Apps\ac\4.3.0\bin>acserver
Create pipe(\\.\pipe\IBMAC\acmasterlog) option(0)
Create pipe(\\.\pipe\IBMAC\acmaster) option(0)
ipcMemCreate...
Shared mem name(acbuffer) size(1048576)
Shared mem error(-514)
Error starting transport layers, Agent controller exiting. See servicelog.log for error report.
The Error number -514 corresponds to OSS_ERR_IPC_CREATE_MAP_FAILED in osserror.h.
Kevin suggests the problem may be in a difference in security setting requirements of Vista when creating the shared mem.
*** Bug 168287 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Karla and Igor, I think this is a severe problem and should be raise to critical/blocker. Majority of TPTP function is not working without RAC and IAC support on this platform.
Given Vista support is a requirement of 4.2.2, I agree that this is a blocker.

Created an attachment (id=55822) The patch changes the name of shared memomory block
The patch changes the name of shared memomory block under Windows from Global\OSSMEMacbuffer to Global/OSSMEMacbuffer. It seems that Vista doesn't like back slashes.
With original name, Win API call CreateFileMapping() gives errcode=5 (access denied)

(In reply to comment #6)
The patch affects Windows only. I've tested it on Vista and XP.

I have reviewed the changes but I have a concern. The Microsoft Platform SDK has never indicated that "/" is a valid namespace separator (please see http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa366537.aspx). It says that "The remainder of the name can contain any character except the backslash character (\)". That may hint that "/" is being treated as a normal character - not a namespace separator. My guess that this fix seems to work because it does not use namespace at all.
I do not have a machine running Windows Terminal Service to test my namespace theory but I guess we should follow the documented API specified by the Microsoft Platform SDK.

In my experience, the "\" is only required when separating the drive name from the directory pathname, such that "C:\tmp\foo" is equivalent to "C:\tmp/foo", and both are acceptable to Windows.
Check out this article. In the section General Guidelines for Supporting Long Filenames it says you can use either backslash or forward slash as a separator and it is supported by all Windows OS's.
http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms810456.aspx
*** Bug 167747 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Several people who have been doing preliminary testing with Vista have reported the need to "Run as administrator" when starting ACServer in order to have a functioning AC. Note that, as part of the User Account Control feature of Vista, logging in as a user in the Administrator group does *not* grant an elevated permission token to applications that you launch. There are several ways to go about getting elevated privileges, and I'll make a suggestion below. Lots of information about the User Account Control feature can be found at http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/windowsvista/aa905108.aspx
There are some tools provided by Microsoft to help determine why a program fails to run when not run as administrator on Vista. I ran ACServer.exe using the "Standard User Analyzer" tool ( http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyID=df59b474-c0b7-4422-8c70-b0d9d3d2f575&DisplayLang=en ) and am attaching the log files generated. Among the many transgressions identified, you can see the use of a restricted namespace ("Global") as one of the operations that requires elevated privileges. So I agree with Samson's suggestion that removing the use of the backslash is not a good solution.
Given the things that have been identified by the Standard User Analyzer as privileged operations, I think it's fair to say the the agent controller routinely performs privileged operations, and at least in the short term, we should consider building it with a manifest that indicates that the process requires administrative privileges. I have seen some notes on how to do this properly, and the most detailed explanation appears in the windows vista developer story help file, which can be downloaded from microsoft here: http://download.microsoft.com/download/D/9/B/D9BEB875-BC1D-4338-A655-251F4F353B2E/Top10Wave.exe From the resulting help file, read the topic Fundamentals -> Secure Applications -> Developing Secure Applications -> User Account Control -> Desiging UAC Applications for Windows Vista -> Step 6: Create and Embed an Application Manifest. Note the special steps required to ensure that the resulting spplication will still run properly on Windows XP.
In parallel to this, I think we should have a moderated discussion about the implications of requiring administrative privs for the agent controller. I have serious doubts that we could refactor the AC to remove the need for any privileged operations, but I still think it's important that we investigate this.
Created an attachment (id=55930) Archive of log files from Standard User Analyzer monitoring ACServer.exe on Vista

Testing AC on Vista shows the following:
- Any ordinary user can launch AC if "Create global objects" option is set for this user or for his group or for "INTERACTIVE" (same as in XP) in Local Security Policy. - Built-in "Administrator" has no restrictions to launch AC (assuming that security setting "Admin Approval Mode for the Build-in Administrator account" has default (unchecked) value). - Other administrative logins (members of "Administrators" group) can launch AC if security setting "Run all administrators in Admin Approval Mode" is unchecked (this is the new Windows security feature introduced in Vista). - With default security settings AC can be launched as Local Service.
So AC can be launched as Local Service or by adjustment of Local Security Policy settings without changing of source code.

Step by step more detailed instructions to set necessary security policy:
1. To open "Local Security Policy" component please click: Start > Control Panel > System and Maintanence > Administrative Tools > Local Security Policy 2. At left panel select "Local Policies" > "User Rights Assignment" 3. At right panel open "Create global object" by double click 4. Add required user or group or built-in security principles category (for example "INTERACTIVE" as done by default in Windows XP) 5. Save settings 6. Log off and log-in as required user

I was successful in running the RAC and IAC using the steps outlined in Comment #14. I was able to Profiling an external Application I was able to Import a remote/local log file I was able to Attach to a remote/local agent and profile an application All of the above scenario's were tested with security enabled where applicable using the TPTP-4.2.2-200701111735 Build.

to be clear on what I meant:
The children of the Require-Bundle header seem to be sorted all the time, for example.

Hi,
In the outline content handler for the bundle source page (Used by quick outline dialog and outline view), I get the require bundle header values directly from the bundle model. In the underlying implementation, the keys are stored using a TreeMap. As a result, I get the keys explicitly in sorted order already.
This problem is also applicable to the import and export package header values.
The outline sorting mechanism works fine for the manifest headers and manifest header values its just some manifest header values are already sorted before the outline sorting mechanism is activated.
Open to suggestions.

Fixed. This turned out to be a problem on my end (rather than the bundle model). A default sort comparator was being used instead of null for the manifest outline view down a couple levels in the class hierarchy.
Patch released to HEAD.

* Added support for using default outline comparators (instead of null) in the content creator interface and implementing classes

bug.short_desc: [Commands] No status from CreateElementCommand#doDefaultElementCreation

long_desc.thetext:
There is currently no way to set the CreateElementCommand's execution status based on the result of the #doDefaultElementCreation() method. If the default element creation fails for any reason (e.g., the use cancels the creation gesture), the CreateElementCommand continues to execute (by configuring the new element that wasn't created), and doesn't return a command result that reflects the failure to create the element.
The CreateElementCommand should check whether or not #doDefaultElementCreation succeeded and return an appropriate command result from #doExecuteWithResult.

Created an attachment (id=55586) Possible solution
This patch allows CreateElementCommand subclasses to set the status of the default element creation, which is returned by #doExecuteWithResult if it is not OK. It minimizes the API change to the addition of one new protected method: #setDefaultElementCreationStatus()

bug.short_desc: RM - Determine approach for Supporting Requirements

long_desc.thetext: Update Concept: Supporting Requirements in accordance with decisions from the December 1 RM content review. See attachment to https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=162636 for details.

I am "re-purposing" this entry based on the following.
We defered the decision on the Artifact: Supporting Requirements and Template: Supporting Requirements during the Nov/Dec RM content reviews. We need to decide our approach to supporting requirements before we commit effort to updating any content. It was proposed on 162639 and 162641 that we use the WIL to capture the Supporting Requirements and the template be removed, respectively.
We have a number of options:
1) Keep the current approach and update the Concept, Guideline, Checklist, in accordance with the associated review comments.
2) Remove all elements related to Supporting Requirements (Artifact, Template, Guideline, Concept, Checklist) and update discussion of WIL (and potentially other elements) to capture the intent of the Supporting Requirements.
3) Keep only the Concept: Supporting Requirements (updated appropriately) and update the discussion of the WIL, referencing this concept.
4) Just ignore non-functional requirements (not a good idea in my opinion)
5) Something else.
I favor option 1). For all other cases we need to review OpenUP/Basic for impact and determine the appropriate course of action.

On the December 20th OpenUP/Basic package owners call there was general consensus that the Supporting Requirements Artifact should remain and the use of the Supporting Requirements Specification to capture the non-functional and global system requirements should remain the recommended representation option with references to the Supporting Requirements captured on the WIL as required. Steve Adolph stated that in his pilot of OpenUP/basic this is indeed how they did it: i.e. WIL captured actions to be done, referencing the Supporting Requirements and Use Cases as required. This worked well.
Use of the WIL to capture Supporting Requirements will remain a valid representation option.
In summary, option 1 of comment #1 was the prefered option.
I will create work items to implement the decisions from the Nov/Dec RM review telecons related to the Supporting Requirements (Concept, Guideline, Checklist, Template, Artifact). I am marking this bug RESOLVED.
Agreed with comment #2. Verified.
Closed based on Package Ownere call discussion.

bug.short_desc: invalid CSS - font family surrounded with escaped quotes

long_desc.thetext:
I set font-family property to Helvetica (no quotes), but it is rendered in HTML as:
Service
Expected and correct format is
Service
This HTML is generated with HTMLRenderOption options = new HTMLRenderOption(); options.setOutputStream(baos); options.setEmbeddable(true); and output starts with:
Created an attachment (id=55685) report with custom font

Ok, more description. It is valid to have quotes around individual font family items. But it is illegal to have quotes surrounding multiple items in font family.
I set Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif into font family for report style in style editor within library. When I look to library XML source, this text is escaped:
<property name="fontFamily">"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"</property>
And then such illegal CSS is generated:
.style_0 { font-family: "Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"; }
So I remove the quotes in the library's XML source:
<property name="fontFamily">Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif</property>
and then this valid CSS is generated:
.style_0 { font-family: "Arial", "Helvetica", sans-serif; }
But if I open the library again, do some changes and save it, this property is quoted again:
<property name="fontFamily">"Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"</property>
This is very annoying, as I must verify correctnes of XML file often.

I have checked the attached design file. The user has creat a new style, which named "report", with the font. This style "report" has not been applied to the text. That means this style is useless for the text.
I have used today's BIRT to open this design file. In the BIRT design interface this style can be edited, but dosen't appear in the "Apply Style" list.
It needs designer team to fix this problem.
I just reproduced it,it's really a bug, I'll check it.

It would be great, if you fixed it soon and perfect, if there would be patch for BIRT 2.1.1. I didn't care about look for month or so, but it starts to be a prolem for us quite soon. Thanks for your work!

Hi,Leos, I checked the history. and I'll explain the reason: 1.Why add quotes to fonts automatically? If the font name is not serif, scans-serif,curisive,fantasy,monospace, we'll add quotes to it.You can see bug 169069 for details. So when you enter "Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"(without quotes), BIRT will treat it as a font name, but not there ones, and add quotes for them.
2.Why can't you use the sytle named "report"? Because there're some predefined styles in BIRT, and "report" is one of them, when you create a style named "report", BIRT will treate it as predefined, and can not be applited to a label, that's the problem exists. In style builder dialog, you can find all the predefined style names.
I suggest you change the name "report" to other strings, and the problem disappear.
My environment is Eclipse 3.3M4, BIRT 2.2.0M4. Waiting for your response, if you think this is not a bug, I'll set it WONTFIX, thanks.

Frank, are you sure, that you entered correct bug number? That bug is about some images ..

Nevertheless the bug is there. I understand this quoting issue, but you do not calculate with possibility of multiple fonts specified here. You should tokenize this value by comma and then apply your quoting rules. Treating as single font name is definitively bug.
ad 2) I don't want to introduce new style report. I know that it is predefined style. I want to alter its definition and set some common styling there for all elements in report. E.g. when I set that font for 'report' style, I want all charts, tables, texts (etc) will use automatically this font. Am I doing it wrong way? This is what I read from documentation.

And Frank: As you say the "report" is a predefined styles in BIRT. But if we allow the user name the style as "report", that is still a bug. But if we allow the > user name the style as "report", that is still a bug. > Please make a change in the BIRT interface: if the name of a style has been > setted as "report", remind the user that this name conflicts with a predefined > styles name when the user press the botton "OK". >

bug.short_desc: SWT library not offered when adding a library

long_desc.thetext: I'm running 3.2.1 on ubuntu. I'm using a 32-bit JDK. WHen I import a project that has a reference to SWT libraries, I get errors. When I go to add a library to the build path, the SWT library is not shown. Why? What do I have to fix?

The will need rerouting.
The 'SWT library' is not part of the platform distro. it arrives in one of the layered bundles. I can't figure out how to figure out which one in any efficient way.
It might be the visual editor.
1) It's unkind that this dependency is so hard to figure out. The library should somehow advertise that it requires some particular collection of plugins.
2) As previously described, it's broken.

IMO, it sounds more like a problem with your installation than a JDT/Core classpath issue. Perhaps you should have asked a question on platform newsgroup instead of opening a bug...
But if you really think there's something wrong here, please describe more precisely steps to reproduce your problem: 1) When you said 'When I go to add a library to the build path, the SWT library is not shown', do you mean that you searched everywhere on your disk and you didn't find it or that you're expecting to find it on the default directory of dialog? 2) How did you try to add the library: using the project properties page on Java Build Path page or modifying the .classpath file? 3) If you used properties page, did you try to 'Add JARs' button of 'Add External JARs...' one?
Do not forget that the more precise you are in the problem description the quicker we can reproduce, understand and fix it...
Close as REMIND as for now, reopen while providing requested info, thanks

I can tell you exactly what happened here, and you can judge whether I have a legitimate gripe with the platform.
The VE bundle adds a library via the extension point for classpath containers.
That library is just named 'SWT'. There is no visual clue whatever that it is part of, and dependent on, the VE bundle.
So, I added this to a project's classpath on a machine with VE installed, and then loaded that project on another machine without VE installed, and I was very confused by the resulting error.
I propose that classpath container tags carry some sort of dependency string so that the error in this case would say, 'this tag is missing BECAUSE YOU DON'T HAVE THE VE BUNDLE INSTALLED.'
If you don't like this idea, then let's route this to VE to ask them to change the name of the library and / or the tag to clearly associate it with VE.
Thanks for the feedback => move to Visual Editor component...

Brief Description Is "... ensuring a synchronized evolution of the work products..." the goal of change management? Perhaps we should focus on using the change mechanisms to assure that we deliver value.
Main Description We need to decide if we want to keep the descriptions of configuration management, as this is out of scope for OpenUP and we don't have much content on it.

We may not need to discuss setting up the Config Mgmt environment though. I think even this light content fits into this package. Calling it into the discipline is tricky though, since disciplines are categories to organize tasks, and we don't have any task for configuration management.

Closing this bug. Work will be tracked under bug duplicate bug 154065.

bug.short_desc: CM - Task: Request Change needs better alignment to OpenUP/Basic disciplines and target audience

long_desc.thetext:
It would be useful to add steps indicating that changes must be evaluated, accepted or rejected, prioritized, estimated, and verified. And that they are not complete until tested.
Add optional inputs Other potential inputs are: Test log, requirements, risk list, implementation, and architecture.

I don't see why to add these steps to Request Change task. This task is, as the name says, about requesting a change only. The acceptance or rejection, prioritization and estimation happen as part of managing the WIL and assignment of those CRs to an iteration. Validation happens when the solution for the CR is developed and tested. I'd rather keep those concerns in separate tasks.

There's nothing in the PM tasks about prioritizing the WIL. Task: Manage Iteration has a step for re-prioritizing if necessary. I think it's fine to evaluate, accept, prioritize, and estimation work items in the PM discipline, but we'll need to create a new Bugzilla entry to add it.

I agree with Ricardo. The dispositioning and prioritizing of change request should be done as part of the PM discipline (of course input from the development team on estimating impact/effort will be required). Shall I raise a bug against the PM discipline?

So we want to make more explicit in the PM task that the WIL is prioritized, and CRs are part of what is being prioritized. If there is anything different about prioritizing a CR than prioritizing a requirement, then it should be described in a guideline.
I wouldn't change the Request Change task or add a Review Change task.

At the February 26, 2007 review of the OpenUP/Basic CM content it was agree that the review and disposition of Change Requests should be done as part of the Iteration Planning within the PM discipline. I raised bug 175573 as a result of this decision. Resolving this bug.
New bug created for PM discipline to handle this.
Closed as the PM bug 175573 is handling this.

bug.short_desc: CM - Guidelines need better alignment to OpenUP/Basic disciplines and target audience

long_desc.thetext:
Change Requests The information in this guideline should be combined with Concept: Change Request. Use this guideline to describe one potential change request cycle for a small project. E.g., how to estimate the impact, how to assign (by volunteering), etc.
Promoting Builds Brief Description In a small team there will probably not be a "set of tiers" through which to promote builds. It will probably just be promoting from the developer workspace to the integration area. There may also be parallel workspaces (sandboxes) such as a demo workspace.
NEW Workspace Add a new guideline describing how small teams should set up and use workspaces, including how to integrate artifacts and using test/integration workspaces. We might want to recommend virtual machine tools such as VMWare so a small team can have multiple workspaces isolated on the same machine.

At the Feb. 26, 2007 OpenUP/Basic CM content review the following decisions were made:
1. Guideline:Change Request Change the name of the Guideline to "Submitting Change Request" so it is clear that this guideline only addresses submission of the change request. Review and disposition of the change request is done as part of PM Task: Plan Iteration.
2. Guideline: Promoting Builds Reduce the number of Verification levels to three: Unit test, Integration Test and System Test to simplify the process for small teams.
3. Proposed Guideline: Workspace We discussed this item and agreed that it was very difficult to provide tool independent guidance as each tool has slightly different workspace (or workarea) management capabilities. We agreed to defer this to future enhancements to OpenUP/Basic (separate plug-ins) via tool mentors.

Incorporated changes from Comment #1 into CVS. Also added some text to the main description of Guideline: Submitting Change Requests to describe the minimum information required on a change request to ensure a speedy review and disposition.
Changes have been made and verified.
Changes incorporated and verified. Closing bug.

bug.short_desc: CM - Concepts need better alignment to OpenUP/Basic disciplines and target audience

long_desc.thetext:
Change Requests This concept needs more content. Add information such as potential change request lifecycles, and describe the "bar" below which minor changes should just be made directly to the artifact without a change request (for small teams).
Workspace This concept needs more motivation and definition. Developers probably already have workspaces on their personal machines, so we should talk about what it means to integrate them effectively.

Change Request There was a conscious decision to conflate all types of change request into the work item. As such, I am not sure we want to discuss proposed lifecycles beyond the recommended lifecycle of a work item. I propose that the description be enhanced to clearly state that all types of change requests are represented in OpenUP/Basic as work items and refer to the Guideline: Work Items List for discussion of lifecycle, attributes, etc.
Regarding the minor/major change, I'm not sure how we should address this. As the CRs represent work items that we would want to track (a bit different than a formal change control process, isn't it). Perhaps a change that will take less than x minutes to implement and test could be done without raising a work item/CR.
Workspace I'm not sure what you are looking for in terms of additional motivation and definition. I'll have to discuss with you.

I discussed this with Jim. We agreed to add some text to the Concept: Change Request explaining that in OpenUP/Basic all change requests are captured on the Work Item List and to capture a reference to the Guideline: Work Item List for recommended attributes for change requests.
The concept: Workspace is ok as is.
I have incorporated this change into CVS. Marking bug resolved.
Resolved by Chris, Verified by Jim. Closing.

bug.short_desc: Package Explorer Filters Ignored

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Startup Eclipse without an activated task 2. Wait for synchronization and all to complete 3. Activate a task (with an existing context) 4. Open Package Explorer
More information: None of the filters are respected in package explorer after the steps enumerated. .* resources are shown, dependancy libraries, etc... The only way to reset this is to deactivate the task and restart Eclipse. This is with Mylar 1.0

Oddly enough, I can't repeat this now. I upgraded Subversive to 1.1RC1 between filing the bug and now, so I would guess that there was some odd conflict between 1.1RC9 and Mylar 1.0 Well, actually there still seems to be a conflict, but unrelated. Will open a new bug for it once I figure out how to repeat.

Daniel: what Mylar does is that once you activate a task *and* the Focus filter is applied to a view (e.g. Package Explorer), it will remove the other filters. This enables your to do things like Alt+clicking to find something in a .settings folder. The way to think about is that Focused mode deprecates the need for manual filters. When the focused mode is unapplied filters are restored. What can happen is that if Eclipse or the VM is killed with Mylar applied filters may not get restored. But if you notice any failure to restore filters that has to do with normal operation please do put steps to reproduce here.

bug.short_desc: CM - Discipline should define some useful reports

long_desc.thetext: Identify a list of reports that would be useful for a small team's change management needs. E.g., trends of new/assigned/closed change requests, number of changes assigned to each person, etc. They should be kept short and simple.

The question is if we should differentiate CRs from any other entry in the WIL. In terms of reporting, would the burndown charts show how the CRs are being addressed? If we run reports on the WIL (sorting by type, status), would that show the same as these reports you suggest?

I think these types of metrics are important and beneficial. However, I agree with Ricardo that they should be captured as part of the PM discipline. I leave it to Ana (new PM package lead) to determine if the burndown charts currently defined are sufficient.

At the February 26, 2007 review of the OpenUP/Basic CM content it was agreed that any additional reports should be defined as part of the PM discipline (potentially associated with Task: Manage Iteration and associated guidance).
I raised bug 175574 as a result of this decision. Resolving this bug.
Verified by Jim Ruehlin. Closing bug.

bug.short_desc: General - Define criteria for establishing basic quality for EPF content

long_desc.thetext:
We need definitive ways to assure an acceptable level of quality in process content prior to releasing that content for initial customer evaluation. This is a list of proposed reviews that should be performed on the content before it can be considered ready for initial release.
Review for readability and consistent voice Follow the authoring guidelines Address passive sentences, grammar errors, improper use of terms, etc Keep descriptions focused on results, not artifacts Visual layout/flow of text
Review for content consistency Discipline focus Role focus Phase focus Content has appropriate links to other content Adherence to OpenUP required fields 1 or 2 templates for each work product
Copy edit review
Review for content correctness Content has been successfully used in real projects Each role and artifact listed in a task (required/optional, input/output) is referenced in the task steps
Review for usability Browser layout Critical portion of guidances are "above the fold" Avoid long intimidating blocks of text Break up using formatting Substitute images for text Text length guidelines Guidances are usually 1-3 screens Task steps are usually 1-3 sentences Whitepapers are 3-10 pages User scenarios PM trying to use process as-is Developer referencing content on patterns Architect trying to formally define the architecture PM trying to justify an approach to management Process engineer adding lots of company specific content Tester adding test guidance specific to a project type etc
Review for Principles and Practices OpenUP practices should be realized in tasks

Jim, thanks for listing the content quality criteria. In general, I agree these are things we should look for. A few comments below.
- I see some of the concerns listed potentially being addressed as part of copy editing the content (of course, it will depend on the copy editor ability to identify those issues), such as: . Address passive sentences, grammar errors, improper use of terms, etc . Visual layout/flow of text . Avoid long intimidating blocks of text . Text length guidelines It doesn't really matter if that is done by a copyeditor or authors/reviewers, I just thought having another pair of eyes looking to content without without being influenced by the in-depth knowledge of methods and processes would provide a less biased perspective.
- Seems to me we can avoid part of the common issues while authoring content and make the reviews pretty straight-forward if we follow the authoring guidelines. Why don't we setup a short (1-2 hours) tutorial to introduce/revisit the authoring guidelines with content authors?
- I don't quite get the item "User Scenarios". Do you mean one would read the content wearing one of those hats (PM, architect, etc.)?

I agree with the criteria for the most part.
I'm not sure we need 1-2 templates per work product. But I'll let that issue work itself out once we get farther down the pike and also when we have examples.
Based on our disparate screen resolution (me being at techie resolution and Jim being and granny resolution), I don't care for your unit of measure of screens for guidance length. I have found that copying and pasting to MS-Word will get us to a unit of measure that will be consistent across all of us. Note though that we'd have to carefully say something like "1-2 pages of description" since we have been excluding header and other linkage type stuff when talking about size.
For your user scenarios I think we need a basic "team member attempting to learn the process for the first time". This "first-timer" perspective will drive us to create the right front door and introductory content. Maybe it should be a persona "Regis, an inexperienced developer who doesn't have much background with agility or the unified process but at least has his screen resolution set higher than 800x600".

It was decided at the 12/18/06 meeting to discuss this topic that the review criteria would be useful. A new bugzilla entry - https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=168464 - has been created for placing this information in the authoring guidelines.
This is a useful set of things to look for when writing and reviewing content. Let's add to the authoring guideline and exercise these criteria on next iterations. Mark bug as verified for now.
*** Bug 167901 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
As per discussion during OpenUP status call today (12/20, 8AM PST), we are closing this bug.

bug.short_desc: build path excludes only partially effective

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: This is a change in behavior versus 3.1 (build ID I20050627-1435). It may be a duplicate of, or related to, Bug ID 105631, although that one and other build-path bugs that I found when searching are about PDE while this one is not.
Given a workspace with two projects:
Project Foo depends upon project Bar. Project Bar contains class bar.Bar with methods one() and two(). Project Foo also contains a folder "bar" with a legacy version of bar.Bar that has method three() but not one() or two(). (I.e., that folder started out as a package within project Foo but was then excluded from Foo's build path when bar was moved into its own project).
In 3.1, all is well. Project Foo uses the definition of bar.Bar from dependent project Bar. The excluded folder does not seem to influence anything. Classes in Foo can call Bar.one() and Bar.two() but not Bar.three().
In 3.2, a build error reports that one() and two() are not defined for class Bar, as though the folder within project Foo is still being used in the build path despite being excluded. Yet, if you edit a class in project Foo, type "Bar." and hit Ctrl-SPACE, the completion list contains one() and two() (from dependent project Bar) but not three() (from the excluded folder). If you select one of those completions, you'll get an error on the call.
Apparently the completion feature and the compiler are using two different sources of information for the members of class bar.Bar.
More information: I will make a workspace with the projects described above available by anonymous FTP as ftp://ftp.newmonics.com/pub/EclipseBug<THIS BUG ID>.tar.gz.
In the tar will be two top-level directories: workspace-3.1 is the workspace as it was created by 3.1; workspace-3.2.1 is what it was like after running 3.2.1 on the original.
Created an attachment (id=71851) Two projects illustrating comment 0 scenario
I cannot reproduce this issue neither using 3.2.2 nor 3.3 RC4.

bug.short_desc: Library management for Runtime does not include required OSGI

long_desc.thetext:
I added the 'SWT' libary to my build path. That makes ErrorDialog and Status available. However, when I try to use the Status constructor, I am rewarded with the following:
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/eclipse/osgi/util/NLS
from
at org.eclipse.core.runtime.Status.<clinit>(Status.java:30)
The SWT library bundle should include this OSGI stuff.
I see jface, moving to UI
Probably needs to move again. The SWT library is defined in one of the layered packaged (visual editing, but I can't figure out which one).
Status is in Core Runtime

Given that this library is only defined in the VE package, why is this core? I'm confused. Or is the idea that this missing class should be in one of the packages that the VE definition is already including?

What exactly are you trying to do? I'm guessing that you: - created a Java project (not a bundle project) - added the SWT library to the build path - things died
If this is the case and you want to use code from runtime then you will have to add other libraries to your build path. Specifically, Status is found in the org.eclipse.equinox.common bundle.

I haven't explained this nearly well enough.
The Visual Edit bundle adds a new 'library' to the build path system, via the defined extension point for this purpose. That library, called SWT, includes several packages. It does not include the package that contains org.eclipse.osgi.util.NLS. I think that this is a bug in that VE extension point, which is why I tried to reroute this bug to them at some point yesterday once I had figured this much out.
Ok, moving to VE. Although I am still not sure of the problem as SWT code should not have any dependancy on OSGi code. But then again I am unfamiliar with the Visual Editor and how it works.
For the record: the VE-implemented SWT classpath container has an option to include JFace. That brings you ErrorDialog, Status, and the connection to the locale code in OSGI.

The problem is that OSGI is a NEW requirement for JFACE. If you look at the official Wiki site, the run JFace outside of Eclipse page does not include OSGI. See http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/JFace
Since at the time VE was released JFace didn't require OSGI, we didn't include it either when JFace was selected in the SWT container.

bug.short_desc: Editor save occurs on the UI thread

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: I20061102-1715
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Edit a java file in eclipse (using the standard java editor) 2. Add a few megs of content in a comment. 3. Save.
Observe: The UI will fail to repaint as the content is written to disk.

Load and save happen in the UI thread per design. Starting with M4 new API is in in-place that will allow to do the save in background (see bug ). However, there are fundamental problems regarding handling of large files and hence marking this one as dup of it.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 75086 ***

(In reply to comment #1) > there are fundamental problems regarding handling of large files and hence > marking this one as dup of it.
I'm less concerned with the handling of large files, and more concerned that the UI thread is being used to perform an operation that could block for a long time (if the EFS provider hits the network, etc). I would prefer to see the editor marked as read-only, the write performed in a job, and the editor unlocked when the job is complete. My use of a large file was just an easy test case.
I skimmed bug 75086 and didn't see any mention of save threading issues. Will that fix address the concerns above?

>I skimmed bug 75086 and didn't see any mention of save threading issues. Will >that fix address the concerns above? Yes. As you can see from the duplicates it is not just load: if you have very large files even editing is a pain. Besides a very limited set of features almost all operations run in the UI and hence you'd see problems.

bug.short_desc: [typing] Pressing 'End' more than once does not trigger a cursor position change event

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: Hello, have a source int CMyOptions::operator[] (const char* name) 1. Cursor at the end of line int CMyOptions::operator[] [(]const char* name)|
2. Moving cursor to the left a) by pressing LEFT key many times b) using mouse int CMyOptions::operator[] (const ch|ar* name)
3. Moving cursor to the end (using END key) int CMyOptions::operator[] (const char* name)| ---
Test2 have a source int CMyOptions::operator[] (const char* name) 1. Cursor at the end of line int CMyOptions::operator[] [(]const char* name)|
2. Moving cursor to the left a) by pressing LEFT key many times b) using mouse int CMyOptions::operator[] (|const char* name[)]
3. Moving cursor to the end (using END key) int CMyOptions::operator[] (const char* name[)]| ---
Test3 have a source int CMyOptions::operator[] (const char* name) 1. Cursor at the end of line int CMyOptions::operator[] [(]const char* name)|
2. Moving cursor to the left a) by pressing LEFT key many times b) using mouse int CMyOptions::operator[[]]| (const char* name)
3. Moving cursor to the end (using END key) int CMyOptions::operator[[]] (const char* name)| ----
More information:

This appears to be a common Text Editor problem. Moving the cursor at the end of the line using the END key does not trigger a cursor position change event when the key is pressed the second time in the same line. I verified this by setting a breakpoint in AbstractTextEditor#handleCursorPositionChanged() which is indeed not called when pressing END the second time. It is also observable by watching the cursor location inormation in the status line. I am pretty sure that the bracket matcher is not painted for the very same reason. Redirecting...

bug.short_desc: Autocomplete disabled inside and after type parameter until import added

long_desc.thetext:
Before import java.util.ArrayList; has been added to the top of a program, typing ArrayList<Int|> and then pressing Ctrl-Space fails to bring up a list of completions e.g. Integer. Also ArrayList<Integer>| followed by Ctrl-Space fails to give the option to import java.util.ArrayList. (It makes sense that this second example should definitely give the import option, because the parameterized type fits ArrayList<T> .)
It would be nice if at any point, matches for parameterized types would give the option of both importing and completing the type simultaneously; e.g. for the first example "ArrayList<Integer> (import java.util.ArrayList)"

Also given
ArrayList<Integer> myList = new |
it would be nice if there was a completion on Ctrl-Space at the indicated cursor position:
"...myList = new ArrayList<Integer>() (import java.util.ArrayList)"
so that something can be filled in at that point without having to go back to ArrayList, hit Ctrl-Space, and return to the end of the line, then hit Ctrl-Space again.

bug.short_desc: [Workbench] [RCP]Create an org.eclipse.ui.ide.application plug-in

long_desc.thetext:
M4
We have many situations where people want to use our resource based APIs but cannot due to a required dependency on the IDE application.
Likewise we have code in the IDE that would like to use other plug-in but cannot due to a circular dependency (specifically the Common Navigator requires the resource parts of the IDE so we can't use it in the IDE without the circular dependency).
Looking at the code in IDE the vast majority of it could be moved to a resources based plug-in with only a small amount left in IDE to support the IDE application and the Resource Perspective.
This would allow 1) RCP apps to use our views like the Problems View with thier own application. Right now many are forced to subclass our (internal) application class to get this to work.
2) The resource navigator to rely only on the new org,eclipse.ui.workbench.resources plug-in thereby allowing the IDE to refer to it.

(In reply to comment #0) > Looking at the code in IDE the vast majority of it could be moved to a > resources based plug-in with only a small amount left in IDE to support the IDE > application and the Resource Perspective.
I thought about this, and if there are no API problems, I believe we should do the following:
- Create a new plug-in org.eclipse.ui.ide.application. - Move the IDE application and supporting classes into the new plug-in (assuming none of them are API). - Fix some of the problems that people have when trying to use org.eclipse.ide without running or subclassing the IDE application class.
This would solve the cyclic dependency problem, and eventually, make org.eclipse.ui.ide a plug-in like any other.
+1 for Boris's suggestion.
Created an attachment (id=56647) Patch to IDE and SDK

Created an attachment (id=56648) org.eclipse.ui.ide.application
Coupled with the attached patches this will fix Bug 155299, Bug 164108 and this bug. I will release this as soon as the PMC gets the new project added
Patch and new plug-in released for build >20070109
platform feature updated with new org.eclipse.ui.ide.application plugin.

Note that this change can break existing clients, e.g. a client that currently only requires 'org.eclipse.ui.ide' and doesn't provide its own application. Did you discuss and accept that breakage?
Maybe a better solution would have been to extract the non-application part into its own plug-in (e.g. 'org.eclipse.ui.ide.base' or 'org.eclipse.ui.resources') and let 'org.eclipse.ui.ide' require that one and re-export all its APIs. Thoughts?
Verified in 20070206-0010

Bug 172517 has reverted the application id to org.eclipse.ui.ide.workbench.
What about Dani's concerns from comment 8? Did you add this to the 3.3 porting guide as a breaking change?

bug.short_desc: [viewcvs] intradocument and interdocument links no longer work

long_desc.thetext: Denis: We have a problem and I need your advice here. In the past, we've used indextools.cgi and indextech.cgi viewcvs links to specify the root= value of documents, such as: http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/indextools.cgi/*checkout*/org.eclipse.emf/doc/org.eclipse.emf.doc/tutorials/slibmod/slibmod.html Because these were path elements rather than querystring parameters, we could link from one doc to another, and also resolve images and CSS files within documents. Now, we get something like this: http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/org.eclipse.emf/doc/org.eclipse.emf.doc/tutorials/slibmod/slibmod.html?root=Tools_Project&view=co (note all the broken images) The reason we have docs in CVS and are trying to web-serve them is because these are also *offline* docs provided by documentation plugins, and we've been successful in the past reusing the same content in Eclipse offline and at eclipse.org online. Some possible solutions here: a) copy documents into org.eclipse/www cvs repo so that these docs can be served properly [annoyance: maintaining two copies of same file in two repos] b) extract files in cvs onto filesystem on download.eclipse.org [annoyance: using download.eclipse.org to serve files which aren't "downloads"] c) enable some method whereby viewcvs knows how to resolve relative links within documents (eg., it rewrites ... as ..., including and tags too. d) Apache rewrite rule so that indextools.cgi/some/path/to/file -> index.cgi/some/path/to/file?root=Tools_Project So, what would you suggest?

With the upgrade from viewcvs 0.X to viewvc 1.0 these custom scripts were not ported. I have created new versions based on the viewvc install and they seme to be working fine.
-M.

Seem to, but aren't. Images are still not resolving and cross-doc links are now resolving to the meta details page instead of the *checkout* path. These are two aspects of the same ongoing problem, which is that the ?view=co part is dropped in , and tags. eg: http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/indextools.cgi/org.eclipse.emf/doc/org.eclipse.emf.doc/tutorials/slibmod/slibmod.html?view=co (broken images, css) click first link to get to: http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/indextools.cgi/org.eclipse.emf/doc/org.eclipse.emf.doc/tutorials/clibmod/clibmod.html instead of http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/indextools.cgi/org.eclipse.emf/doc/org.eclipse.emf.doc/tutorials/clibmod/clibmod.html?view=co

Fixed. The issue was the default action, and the deprication of the var that used to control it.
# checkout_magic: Use checkout links with magic /*checkout*/ prefixes so # checked out HTML pages can have working links to other repository files # Note: This option is DEPRECATED and should not be used in new ViewVC # installations. Setting "default_file_view = co" achieves the same effect
-M.
Verified, we're all good, at least until we have to move from /cvsroot/tools to /cvsroot/modeling. At that point you'll probably hear me kvetching about needing an indexmodeling.cgi. ;-)

bug.short_desc: Error with Expressions and multiple debug sessions

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060629-1905
Steps To Reproduce: Enter the debug view. Open two debug sessions, a JAVA-Session J and some other session (non-java) D (for example C/C++). write some expressions that can be evaluated in D but not in J (eg. using C/C++ only constructs). The problem: Eclipse reports errors when both are suspended and one changes the focus (==klicking to a stackframe) from D (where the expressions are evaluated correctly) to J (where they cannot be evaluated, when it should just silently mark them "invalid" (red).
More information: I traced that down to the class org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.WatchExpression:
Eclipse calls the "setExpressionContext()" method, since the context was changed from D to J. This in turn calls "evaluate" for reciving the result of the expression from J. However, the old value of the expression, obtained by D, is still stored in fResult.
Now when "evaluate()" calls "setPending()", a watchExpressionChanged is fired, and since J already registered for that, it calls "getValue()" (The call comes from "JDIModelPresentation.getExpressionText()"). getValue() however will return the _old_ value stored in fResult (This might be a race condition), and since that old value is some class from my own debugger D, J gets confused and throws an error.
IMHO, WatchExpression.setPending(true) should set fResult to null to invalidate the old result.
*** Bug 167896 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 167897 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 167898 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 167899 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: Error with Expressions and multiple debug sessions

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060629-1905
Steps To Reproduce: Enter the debug view. Open two debug sessions, a JAVA-Session J and some other session (non-java) D (for example C/C++). write some expressions that can be evaluated in D but not in J (eg. using C/C++ only constructs). The problem: Eclipse reports errors when both are suspended and one changes the focus (==klicking to a stackframe) from D (where the expressions are evaluated correctly) to J (where they cannot be evaluated, when it should just silently mark them "invalid" (red).
More information: I traced that down to the class org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.WatchExpression:
Eclipse calls the "setExpressionContext()" method, since the context was changed from D to J. This in turn calls "evaluate" for reciving the result of the expression from J. However, the old value of the expression, obtained by D, is still stored in fResult.
Now when "evaluate()" calls "setPending()", a watchExpressionChanged is fired, and since J already registered for that, it calls "getValue()" (The call comes from "JDIModelPresentation.getExpressionText()"). getValue() however will return the _old_ value stored in fResult (This might be a race condition), and since that old value is some class from my own debugger D, J gets confused and throws an error.
IMHO, WatchExpression.setPending(true) should set fResult to null to invalidate the old result.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 167895 ***

bug.short_desc: Caption cut off in "Import Symptom Database" window

long_desc.thetext:
Hardware Environment:
Software Environment:
Build: SymptomEditor.win32.win32.x86-TPTP-4.4.0-200612131105
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Import a SDB
Actual Results: In the window, notice that the caption is cut off
Expected Results: Message should not be cut off.
Additional Information: See attached screenshot
Created an attachment (id=55601) Screenshot
Rough estimate: 8h.
Targetting to iteration 3 and increasing priority to indicate it is planned for 4.4.

This problem occurs when the screen size of the Windows are relatively smaller (such as 800x600 in size) than the size (height) of the Import Symptom Catalog File Wizard dialog.
The lower blank area of the dialog is reserved for the progress monitor and the area is partially hiding the "Open editor after import" check box due to the limited height of the Wizard Dialog.
The symptom import operation is now performed in the background (bugzilla 137186) so that the progress monitor in the Wizard dialog can be removed. This will prevent the caption cut off.

There are two ways to show the Import Symptom Catalog Wizard dialog as follows.
1. Select File->Import... menu. From the Import dialog, choose Profiling and Logging->Symptom Catalog File and click Next button.
2. From the Log Navigator view, right click the tree node and select Import Symptom Catalog menu.
I was able to remove the progress monitor only for the No. 2 case with the attached patch, but it did not work for the No. 1 case.
There would need more investigation for the No.1 case...
Created an attachment (id=64433) Temporary patch for 167900

Found a relating bug 19462 regarding org.eclipse.jface.wizard.WizardDialog.
It appears that we cannot omit the blank area which is reserved for the progress monitor even when we set the setNeedsProgressMonitor() to false with the latest jface code...
Alex, now I have no idea how to fix this defect. Can we describe the minimum screen size requirement in the documentation to avoid the caption cut off?
We could place the content of the page into a scrolled composite, so at least we get a vertical scrool bar in the case were the content doesn't fit.
Thank you for the comment, Alex. I have added a vertical scroll bar to be shown when the composite area of ImportSymptomDBPage2 is small. Please review the new patch being attached.
Created an attachment (id=64671) Patch for VScroll bar on ImportSymptomDBPage2
By the way, please assign this bug to me (as it is already assigned). :-)
I have verified the patch, please mark the defect as fixed.
COnfirmed that the patch has been checked in CVS.

attachment.desc: Patch for VScroll bar on ImportSymptomDBPage2
